title: Letters: Frydenberg's interest rate fairytale doesn't add up
text:
Low rates not the way to economic prosperity

RBA governor Philip Lowe, like your columnist Christopher Joye, makes a huge mistake in assuming that further interest rate cuts are going to boost employment and inflation.

It is profitable opportunities that primarily drive investment, not the availability or cost of capital.

Ironically, it is abnormally low rates for too long that have contributed to the drying up of opportunities, creating overcapacity in many industries and enabling inefficient, unprofitable companies to stay in business. Low rates have also pushed asset prices higher, generating superior returns for speculative investment rather than traditional business investment.

You cannot manipulate your way to prosperity; it has to be earned. Attempts to do so simply enrich some at the expense of others, and result in distortions and unintended negative consequences.

Mark Engelbrecht

Floreat, WA

Solar’s stellar ROI beats the banks and equities

The AFR View ‘‘When energy tribes fight, the big stick rules’’ (October 10) missed a significant driver behind the uptake of solar power by households. Interest rates are at historic lows and the return on investment of solar panels is, literally, an order of magnitude or more better than anything available through banks, equity or financial instruments. This is the case whether you factor in government subsidies or not. Best of all, it’s a guaranteed return, through power costs avoided, or income from selling power into the grid, or both.

If you have around $10,000 to invest, forget the stockmarket; these days it’s almost impossible to beat the return you get from the installation of solar panels.

Russell Colman

Safety Beach, Vic

Super expense ratios are simply profiteering

The conclusion that the retail super industry is becoming more competitive by reducing its fees (October 8) does your readers a disservice by failing to point out how ludicrously high expense ratios remain across the entire superannuation industry.

To claim that an average fee (as a percentage of account balance) of 1.11per cent represents a good outcome ignores the reality that the $31.8 billion in fees Australians pay every year are going to the pockets of overpaid fund managers.

Australians would do well to read the words of the legendary pioneer of index funds, John Bogle, who in the mid 1970s began to offer extremely low-cost funds to mum and dad investors. Today these types of funds are available to all Australians, and they have expense ratios as low as 0.03per cent.

Please do your readers a favour and report on their interests, not those of the profiteering super industry (both retail and industry).

Advertisement

Jack Goodman

Mosman, NSW

Betrayal of Kurds is history repeating itself

I enjoyed Phillip Coorey’s article ‘‘America’s allies can’t ignore Trump’s latest message’’, (October 11). He seems to be one of the few commentators who have an understanding of the Kurds beyond superficial media stereotypes.

The Kurds number well over 35million people, spread over several troubled Middle Eastern countries. The numbers vary because some countries, like Turkey, deny they are a definite ethnic group. Some call them simply Mountain Arabs. They are the largest nation in the world without their own country, despite a broken promise to give them one after World War II. Despite many betrayals, the Kurdish people have remained loyal to supporters such as the US that have let them down so often in the past.

Bob Muirhead

Port Melbourne, Vic

Reverse factoring isn’t evil but terms can be

Discussion of reverse factoring is analogous to the gun debate in the US. Clearly the gun isn’t evil, but the way it is used may be.

Reverse factoring, provided at a competitive cost and with equitable terms and conditions, used to obtain early payment of an invoice with fair payment terms, should be a useful financial product.

A transaction where unfair payment terms are imposed on a supplier, combined with reverse factoring to bring forward the payment, at the expense of the supplier is "evil".

The real ‘‘evil’’ is unfair payment terms being imposed on suppliers, which should be addressed.

Danny Sargeant

Curtin, ACT

Harvard seems to miss the point of education

Advertisement

The Harvard University study on international trade (October 12-13) omits education as an Australian export, which the Financial Review has previously acknowledged is ‘‘the country’s third-largest export industry and worth $32.4 billion to the economy’’.

Perhaps the study counted education under Travel & Tourism, a ‘‘low complexity’’ category. Whatever the explanation, something seems amiss.

Janet Burstall

Lilyfield, NSW

Do NAB’s computers get paid penalty rates?

While NAB’s Phil Chronican is cleaning out the Augean stables, can he ensure the computer keeps working on weekends. If I transfer funds on Friday, it doesn’t show up until Monday, whereas if transferred on Monday it will be credited on Tuesday. Must be worth a smidgen of interest to the bank to shut down transfers over weekends.

Paul Everingham

Hamilton, Qld
